Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Before we get to questions, I’ll summarize today’s policy action by the Federal Open Market Committee and then place the Committee’s decision in the context of our economic outlook and our collective judgment about the appropriate path of monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: As indicated in the statement released earlier this afternoon, the Committee is maintaining a highly accommodative policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to ¼ percent, and we continue to anticipate that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate at least through late 2014.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In addition, the Committee decided to continue through the end of the year our program of lengthening the maturity of our securities holdings rather than completing the program this month as previously scheduled.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Specifically, the Committee intends to purchase Treasury securities with remaining maturities of 6 years to 30 years at the current pace and to sell or redeem an equal amount of Treasury securities with remaining maturities of approximately 3 years or less.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The details of our plans for our securities purchases and sales were described in an accompanying statement released today and can be found on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York’s website.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The continuation of the maturity extension program should put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates and make broader financial conditions more accommodative than they would otherwise be, thereby supporting economic recovery.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In conjunction with today’s meeting, FOMC participants—the 7 Board members and the 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted their individual economic projections and policy assessments for the years 2012 to 2014 and over the longer run.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: These projections are important continues to expand at a moderate pace in the face of headwinds generated by the situation in Europe, a still-depressed housing market, tight credit for some borrowers, and fiscal restraint at the federal, state, and local levels.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Business and household spending are increasing at rates consistent with moderate economic growth, though household spending appears to be rising at a somewhat slower pace than earlier this year.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Employment gains have been smaller in recent months, and the unemployment rate, at 8.2 percent, remains elevated.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In light of these developments, Committee participants have generally marked down their projections for economic growth, but most still see the economy as expanding at a moderate pace over coming quarters and then picking up gradually.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Based on their projections for economic growth, FOMC participants foresee slower progress in reducing unemployment than they did in April.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Committee participants’ projections for the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter of this year have a central tendency of 8.0 to 8.2 percent, declining to 7.0 percent to 7.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 2014, levels that would remain above participants’ estimates of the longer-run normal rates of unemployment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In addition to projecting only slow progress in bringing down unemployment, most participants see the risks to the outlook weighted mainly toward slower growth and higher unemployment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In particular, participants noted that strains in global financial markets, associated principally with the situation in Europe, continue to pose significant risks to the recovery and to further improvement in labor market conditions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Meanwhile, inflation has declined recently, primarily reflecting lower prices of crude oil and gasoline.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Longer-term inflation expectations have remained stable, and the Committee anticipates that inflation over the medium run will run at or below the 2 percent rate that it judges specifically, participants’ projections of inflation have a central tendency of 1.2 to 1.7 percent for 2012 and 1.5 to 2.0 percent for 2014.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The economic projections submitted by FOMC participants are conditioned on their individual assessments of the appropriate path of monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: As you can see from the chart, Committee participants have a range of views about when the initial increase in the federal funds rate is likely to be warranted.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: After a thorough discussion of those views, and of the ongoing uncertainty and risks surrounding the outlook, the FOMC—as I mentioned—maintained its collective judgment that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels for the federal funds rate at least through late 2014, and it agreed to provide further support to the economy by continuing the maturity extension program.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The Committee is prepared to take further action as appropriate to promote a stronger economic recovery and sustained improvement in labor market conditions in a context of price stability.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I’d be glad to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Steve Liesman, CNBC.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, looking back on the last four years of Fed policy, I think it’s probably fair to say it has been bold and yet at the same time halting.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: You did QE1 and then you stopped and then you did QE2.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: You did “Operation Twist” and you told us it was going to end in June; now you’ve extended it.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: How would you respond if, several years from now, a young MIT graduate student came forward and said, “You know what the problem with Fed policy was during this period is it was too incremental, and that the reason why the economy underperformed was because of that incrementalism.”  And what do you think the dangers are right now that today’s action is also too incremental?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: a continuous fashion until December of 2008.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: And since then, we’ve been operating with nonstandard monetary tools, including asset purchases and extension of maturities.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: By their nature, these tend to be lumpy.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: We haven’t done them in a continuous way.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: But our view of the effects of these programs on the economy is that the total stock of outstanding securities in our portfolio is what determines the level of accommodation that the economy is receiving.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: So in that respect, it wouldn’t be really a start and stop; rather, whenever we have stopped purchasing, the level of accommodation that was already in the system remains there until conditions warrant further action.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Now, underlying all this, of course, is the fact that the outlook has changed.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Like many other forecasters, the Federal Reserve was too optimistic early in the recovery about the pace of recovery.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: And we’ve had to add additional accommodation going forward, as we have seen, in fact, that the headwinds have kept the recovery from being as strong as we would like.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: But, again, by the nature of these unconventional tools, they are—tend to be more discreet in their size, but they continue to have accommodative effects even after the pattern of purchases has ended.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Don’t you worry about incrementalism now?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Well, we’ve taken a step today, which is a substantive step, which will provide additional accommodation for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And, moreover, we have stated that we’re prepared to take further steps if necessary to promote sustainable growth and recovery in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, we are prepared to do what’s necessary.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We are prepared to provide support for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Mark Felsenthal with Reuters.
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, many analysts have characterized today’s step as somewhat modest.
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: Your own outlook has a much lower GDP the unemployment rate through the end of this year.
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: The program itself is smaller and of shorter duration than the original Operation Twist.
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: Given this weaker outlook, why such a modest program?
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: And when you say you are prepared to take further action, which is a stronger characterization than in your last meeting, does that mean you are prepared to do a full-on new asset purchase program?
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: Well, there’s been a great deal of economic news since our last meeting.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The incoming data were somewhat disappointing—but not entirely clear how to read them.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We had issues with weather and seasonal adjustment and other factors.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We’ve seen some of those effects in financial markets.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, I think, there is some case to be made for making some additional judgments about where the economy is going.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That being said, the step we took, the extension of the maturity extension program, I think, is a substantive step, and it will provide some additional support.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And yes, additional asset purchases would be among the things that we would certainly consider if we need to take additional measures to strengthen the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Jon Hilsenrath from the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, I’d like to ask you to respond to a different set of criticisms.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: This criticism—which you hear from Capitol Hill and Wall Street and different places—is that the Fed has already pushed interest rates to an extraordinarily low level, a historically low level, and that there isn’t anything more that the Fed can do to help the recovery.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: That—the criticism is that the Fed at this point should stand down and let Congress or the White House attend to the economy’s ailments or let market forces attend to the economy’s ailments.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: What do you think of those arguments, and how would you respond to them?
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: panacea.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Monetary policy by itself is not going to solve our economic problems.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: We welcome help and support from any other part of the government, from other economic policymakers.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: So, collaboration is—would be great.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: I wouldn’t accept the proposition, though, that the Fed has no more ammunition.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: I do think that our tools, while they are nonstandard, still can create more-accommodative financial conditions, can still provide support for the economy, can still help us return to a more normal economic situation.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: That being said, again, any other support that is forthcoming, any other economic policies that are undertaken that are helpful in terms of making our economy stronger are welcome.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: But I do think that monetary policy still does have some capacity to strengthen the economy by easing financial conditions.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Mitt Romney recently said that QE2 had a relatively little impact on the economy.
Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Do you agree that QE2 had little effect on the economy?
Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Do you think the President’s policies has had an effect on the effectiveness of monetary policy?
Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Sentences: And do you think it’s appropriate for a presidential candidate to comment on the future path of monetary policy?
Speaker: ZACH GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Well, I’ll just say first that we think that both of the asset purchase programs, so-called QE1 and QE2, did have significant effects on asset prices and financial conditions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And although there were certain problems in transmission—for example, the housing market has not been as responsive as it’s been in some times in the past—we do think that they were both effective in providing support for the economy, and in particular, so-called QE2 ended what looked to be an incipient deflation problem when we first introduced it.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, I do think those have been effective, and as I said to Mr. Hilsenrath, we think that these kinds want to reiterate that the Federal Reserve is nonpartisan, we are very serious about taking our decisions based on purely economic grounds without political considerations, and we’ll continue to do that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentences: Jim Puzzanghera with the L.A. Times.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentences: Long-term interest rates, mortgage rates are already at historic lows.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentences: How much more help can an extension of Operation Twist do and—to lower interest rates?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentences: Well, the interest rates are quite low, and they’re being pushed down more by safe-haven flows and other factors.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That being said, I think we can lower interest rates more.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But beyond that, Operation Twist and asset purchases work also through other channels.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In particular, by acquiring securities in the market and bringing them onto the Fed’s balance sheet, we essentially induce investors to move into substitute securities.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, for example, an investor who sells a Treasury security to the Fed may end up buying a corporate bond instead, and so the effect will be to lower corporate bond rates and corporate spreads.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Or a bank may, having sold its Treasury securities, may decide to make a loan instead.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, it’s not just the effect on the long-term interest rate, but there’s a broader set of effects that feed through other asset prices, other interest rates, other spreads, and provide a broader ease in financial conditions which is supportive to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you.

Speaker: JEFF KEARNS.

Sentences: Kristina Peterson, Dow Jones.
Speaker: KRISTINA PETERSON.

Sentences: I know that you’ve said that European policymakers are the first line of defense for the European debt crisis, but under what circumstances would the Fed decide to get more directly involved or coordinate action with other central banks?

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We try to provide whatever help and support we can.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We did, of course, coordinate earlier in the provision of the dollar swaps to other central banks, which have been useful in reducing pressures in dollar funding markets and allowing European banks to continue lending in dollars, including to U.S. borrowers.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, at this point, we are consulting frequently.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We are prepared to work together if that can be done constructively.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But at this point, you know, we are mostly just in consultation mode.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Peter Barnes, Fox Business.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Sir, you had talked about trying to get maybe a little help from some of the other branches of government, so that leads to the questions about the “fiscal cliff.”  Have you seen any evidence that the lack of progress on resolving the fiscal-cliff issue is having an impact on the economy right now?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Is it slowing economic growth seeing it, and if you haven’t seen it yet, when could we—might we start to see it hit the economy and hurt the economy?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Well, I think it’s still a bit early, but as we move forward in the year, we do anticipate that the uncertainty associated with the so-called fiscal cliff will have some economic effects.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We heard anecdotes today in the meeting about firms that might be government contractors that were, you know, not sure about whether the contracts would still be in place come January and making employment decisions based on that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: More generally, financial markets don’t like uncertainty and, particularly, uncertainty of this magnitude, and that, I think, will be a negative.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So that uncertainty is there, that’s going to be an issue.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I think most importantly, though, is that Congress get the policy right.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I’ve talked about three elements for fiscal policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The first is to do no harm as far as the recovery is concerned, to try to avoid a fiscal cliff that would significantly damage the recovery.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But second, to maintain the effort to achieve a sustainable fiscal path over the longer term.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And third, to use fiscal policy effectively—to have a better tax code, to make good use of government spending programs and make them efficient and effective, and so on.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I think if Congress does all those things, the ultimate benefits would be substantial.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Peter Cook with Bloomberg Television.

Sentences: If I could follow up on my colleague Peter Barnes’s question regarding the fiscal cliff, just listening to your answer here, how beneficial would it be for the U.S. economy right now, given some of the talk on Capitol Hill that the lawmakers and the Administration deal with the fiscal-cliff issues, perhaps temporarily kick the can down the road into next year, deal with it sooner rather than later.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, there has been impact through lower interest rates, but I think more broadly is the indirect couple of years, then they’re more likely to expand, to add capital, to add products, and, consequently, they are more likely to hire.
